question_text: Is the establishment ensuring that no discrimination exists among employees on the ground of gender regarding wages for the same or similar nature of work?
applicability_criteria: All establishments employing male, female, or transgender employees performing similar work
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify all employees performing same or similar work.
2. Compare wage rates across genders for these roles.
3. Ensure no disparity exists solely based on gender.
4. Document job descriptions and skill assessments to justify any non-gender-based variances.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Payroll records showing equal pay for same roles; Job descriptions; Anti-discrimination policy
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Pending wage adjustments; Dispute resolution records regarding equal pay

legal_text: There shall be no discrimination in an establishment or any unit thereof among employees on the ground of gender in matters relating to wages by the same employer, in respect of the same work or work of a similar nature done by any employee.

question_text: Has the employer refrained from reducing the wage rates of any employee for the purpose of complying with gender non-discrimination provisions?
applicability_criteria: All establishments adjusting wages to comply with equal remuneration
simplified_guidance:
1. Review wage history before and after equal pay adjustments.
2. Confirm that higher-paid employees' wages were not lowered to meet the lower threshold.
3. Ensure adjustments are made by raising the lower wages to the higher level.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Historical payroll data; Wage revision letters

legal_text: No employer shall for the purposes of complying with the provisions of sub-section (1), reduce the rate of wages of any employee.

question_text: Does the establishment ensure no discrimination on the ground of sex during recruitment for the same work or work of similar nature?
applicability_criteria: All establishments during the hiring process
simplified_guidance:
1. Review recruitment policies and job advertisements.
2. Ensure selection criteria are gender-neutral.
3. Verify offer letters for similar roles to ensure consistent terms of employment.
4. Exception applies only if employment of women is legally prohibited in that specific work.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Recruitment policy; Job postings; Interview records

legal_text: No employer shall make any discrimination on the ground of sex while recruiting any employee for the same work or work of similar nature and in the conditions of employment, except where the employment of women in such work is prohibited or restricted by or under any law for the time being in force.

question_text: Are all employees paid wages at a rate not less than the minimum rate of wages notified by the appropriate Government?
applicability_criteria: All employers
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify the applicable minimum wage notification for the region and industry.
2. Compare notified rates against the wages paid to all categories of employees.
3. Ensure basic pay plus dearness allowance meets the minimum threshold.
4. Rectify any shortfalls immediately.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Monthly wage register; Official Minimum Wage Notification copy
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Arrears calculation sheet; Proof of payment of differential wages

legal_text: No employer shall pay to any employee wages less than the minimum rate of wages notified by the appropriate Government.

question_text: Are the minimum wages paid by the establishment equal to or higher than the floor wage fixed by the Central Government for the geographical area?
applicability_criteria: All establishments in areas where a Floor Wage is notified
simplified_guidance:
1. Check the Central Government notification for the Floor Wage applicable to your area.
2. Ensure the state minimum wage is not lower than this floor wage.
3. If the state wage is lower, pay the floor wage rate.
4. If the employer was paying higher than the floor wage earlier, ensure wages are not reduced.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Wage comparison sheet; Floor wage notification
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Internal memo acknowledging floor wage adjustments

legal_text: The minimum rates of wages fixed by the appropriate Government under section 6 shall not be less than the floor wage and if the minimum rates of wages fixed by the appropriate Government earlier is more than the floor wage, then, the appropriate Government shall not reduce such minimum rates of wages fixed by it earlier.

question_text: Does the employer pay wages for a full normal working day to employees who work less than the requisite hours, provided the failure to work was not due to the employee's unwillingness?
applicability_criteria: Employees whose minimum wage is fixed by the day
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify days where employees worked partial hours.
2. Determine the cause: Employer failure to provide work vs. Employee unwillingness.
3. If it was the employer's failure, pay the full daily wage.
4. Document reasons for partial work in the register.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Attendance register; Wage slips; Incident reports for short work

legal_text: If an employee whose minimum rate of wages has been fixed under this Code by the day works on any day on which he was employed for a period of less than the requisite number of hours constituting a normal working day, he shall, save as otherwise hereinafter provided, be entitled to receive wages in respect of work done on that day, as if he had worked for a full normal working day.

question_text: Where an employee performs two or more classes of work with different minimum wage rates, are wages paid according to the time spent on each class at the respective rates?
applicability_criteria: Employees performing mixed roles with different wage tiers
simplified_guidance:
1. Track time spent on each specific class of work (e.g., skilled vs. semi-skilled tasks).
2. Apply the applicable minimum wage rate for the hours spent on each task.
3. Calculate total daily wage based on this breakdown.
4. Ensure the total is not less than the minimum rate for the respective classes.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Time sheets showing task breakdown; Wage calculation records

legal_text: Where an employee does two or more classes of work to each of which a different minimum rate of wages is applicable, the employer shall pay to such employee in respect of the time respectively occupied in each such class of work, wages at not less than the minimum rate in force in respect of each such class.

question_text: For employees on piece work where a minimum time rate is fixed, does the employer pay wages at not less than the minimum time rate?
applicability_criteria: Establishments employing piece-rate workers
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify employees paid on a piece-rate basis.
2. Check if a minimum time rate (e.g., daily/hourly minimum wage) is fixed for their category.
3. Compare piece-rate earnings against the minimum time rate for the hours worked.
4. Pay the shortfall if piece-rate earnings are lower than the minimum time rate.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Piece-rate production records; Daily wage comparison sheet

legal_text: Where a person is employed on piece work for which minimum time rate and not a minimum piece rate has been fixed under this Code, the employer shall pay to such person wages at not less than the minimum time rate.

question_text: Has the employer fixed the number of hours of work that constitute a normal working day, inclusive of specified intervals?
applicability_criteria: All establishments employing workers with minimum wage rates
simplified_guidance:
1. Define the normal working hours per day (typically 8-9 hours).
2. Include rest intervals in the calculation of the working day where required.
3. Display these hours on the notice board.
4. Ensure compliance with state-specific rules regarding daily limits.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Notice Board display of working hours; Standing Orders; Employee Handbook

legal_text: Where the minimum rates of wages have been fixed under this Code, the appropriate Government may fix the number of hours of work which shall constitute a normal working day inclusive of one or more specified intervals.

question_text: Is a day of rest provided to every employee in every period of seven days?
applicability_criteria: All employees in the establishment
simplified_guidance:
1. Schedule one mandatory weekly off day for every 7-day cycle.
2. Ensure this rest day is paid if required by the minimum wage notification.
3. Maintain a roster showing rest days for all employees.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Attendance Register; Shift Roster; Weekly Off records

legal_text: Where the minimum rates of wages have been fixed under this Code, the appropriate Government may provide for a day of rest in every period of seven days which shall be allowed to all employees or to any specified class of employees and for the payment of remuneration in respect of such days of rest.

question_text: Are employees compensated at a rate not less than the overtime rate if they are required to work on their designated day of rest?
applicability_criteria: Employees working on their weekly off day
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify instances where employees worked on their weekly rest day.
2. Verify the payment made for that specific day.
3. Ensure the rate paid is at least the overtime rate (typically double).
4. Check if a compensatory rest day was also provided.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Overtime Register; Wage Slips showing rest day pay

legal_text: Where the minimum rates of wages have been fixed under this Code, the appropriate Government may provide for payment for work on a day of rest at a rate not less than the overtime rate.

question_text: Is overtime paid at a rate not less than twice the normal rate of wages for any work done in excess of the normal working day?
applicability_criteria: All employees working beyond normal fixed hours
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify the 'normal rate of wages' for the employee.
2. Verify time records for hours worked beyond the daily limit (e.g., >8 or 9 hours).
3. Calculate the overtime payable at 2x the normal rate.
4. Ensure payment is for every hour or part of an hour worked in excess.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Overtime Register; Payroll records; Attendance logs vs Payment logs

legal_text: Where an employee whose minimum rate of wages has been fixed under this Code by the hour, by the day or by such a longer wage-period as may be prescribed, works on any day in excess of the number of hours constituting a normal working day, the employer shall pay him for every hour or for part of an hour so worked in excess, at the overtime rate which shall not be less than twice the normal rate of wages.

question_text: Has the establishment correctly applied exemptions for intermittent or emergency work only to the classes of employees prescribed by the appropriate Government?
applicability_criteria: Establishments claiming exemptions from standard working hours
simplified_guidance:
1. List employees categorized as 'intermittent', 'preparatory', or 'emergency' workers.
2. Verify if these categories match the specific exemptions prescribed by the Government.
3. Ensure standard limits are not bypassed for non-exempt employees.
4. Document the justification for intermittent classification.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: List of exempt employees; Job descriptions justifying intermittent nature

legal_text: The provisions of sub-section (1) shall, in relation to the following classes of employees apply, only to such extent and subject to such conditions as may be prescribed... employees engaged in any emergency... preparatory or complementary work... essentially intermittent... technical reasons... irregular action of natural forces.

question_text: Are wages paid to employees only through authorized modes such as current coin, currency notes, cheque, bank credit, or electronic mode?
applicability_criteria: All establishments
simplified_guidance:
1. Verify the method of wage payment used for all employees.
2. Ensure it falls under the authorized categories (Cash, Cheque, Bank Transfer, Digital).
3. If a specific notification exists for your industry requiring digital/bank payment only, ensure strict compliance.
4. Avoid payment via promissory notes or barter.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bank advice slips; Cash payment vouchers with signatures; Cheque counterfoils

legal_text: All wages shall be paid in current coin or currency notes or by cheque or by crediting the wages in the bank account of the employee or by the electronic mode: Provided that the appropriate Government may, by notification, specify the industrial or other establishment, the employer of which shall pay to every person employed in such industrial or other establishment, the wages only by cheque or by crediting the wages in his bank account.

question_text: Has the employer fixed a wage period for employees that does not exceed one month?
applicability_criteria: All establishments
simplified_guidance:
1. Define the wage period (Daily, Weekly, Fortnightly, or Monthly).
2. Ensure the duration does not exceed one month (e.g., Quarterly payment is prohibited).
3. Document this period in the employment contract and standing orders.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Standing Orders; Appointment Letters; Notice of wage period

legal_text: The employer shall fix the wage period for employees either as daily or weekly or fortnightly or monthly subject to the condition that no wage period in respect of any employee shall be more than a month.

question_text: Are wages paid within the statutory time limits prescribed for the respective wage period (e.g., by the 7th of the succeeding month for monthly earners)?
applicability_criteria: All establishments based on their fixed wage period
simplified_guidance:
1. Daily earners: Pay at the end of the shift.
2. Weekly earners: Pay on the last working day of the week.
3. Fortnightly earners: Pay before the end of the 2nd day after the fortnight.
4. Monthly earners: Pay before the expiry of the 7th day of the succeeding month.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bank transfer timestamps; Wage Register with payment dates
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Reasons for delay recorded in register

legal_text: The employer shall pay or cause to be paid wages to the employees, engaged on... (i) daily basis, at the end of the shift; (ii) weekly basis, on the last working day of the week... (iii) fortnightly basis, before the end of the second day after the end of the fortnight; (iv) monthly basis, before the expiry of the seventh day of the succeeding month.

question_text: In cases of removal, dismissal, retrenchment, or resignation, are wages paid within two working days of the termination of employment?
applicability_criteria: Employees leaving service due to resignation, dismissal, or retrenchment
simplified_guidance:
1. Track dates of resignation, dismissal, or removal.
2. Ensure full and final settlement (wages) is processed within 2 working days.
3. Obtain acknowledgment of receipt from the employee.
4. Note: This timeline is strictly 2 working days, unlike the general 7th day rule.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Full and Final Settlement records; Bank payment proofs
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Proof of employee non-availability for settlement

legal_text: Where an employee has been... removed or dismissed from service; or... retrenched or has resigned from service, or became unemployed due to closure of the establishment, the wages payable to him shall be paid within two working days of his removal, dismissal, retrenchment or, as the case may be, his resignation.

question_text: Does the proprietor, firm, or company accept ultimate responsibility for the payment of all dues under the Code if the immediate employer fails to pay?
applicability_criteria: Proprietors, Companies, Firms
simplified_guidance:
1. Establish a clear hierarchy of payment responsibility.
2. If contractors or immediate supervisors fail to pay, the principal employer/proprietor must settle dues.
3. Maintain indemnity clauses in contracts with third-party manpower agencies.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Service Agreements; Payment records to contract labor
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Notices sent to contractors regarding non-payment

legal_text: Every employer shall pay all amounts required to be paid under this Code to every employee employed by him: Provided that where such employer fails to make such payment in accordance with this Code, then, the company or firm or association or any other person who is the proprietor of the establishment, in which the employee is employed, shall be responsible for such payment.

question_text: In the event of an employee's death, are undisbursed dues paid to the nominated person or deposited with the prescribed authority?
applicability_criteria: Cases where an employee dies before wage settlement
simplified_guidance:
1. Ensure all employees have valid nominations on file.
2. Upon death, pay dues to the nominee.
3. If no nominee exists or payment cannot be made, deposit the amount with the Authority prescribed by the Government.
4. Retain proof of deposit to discharge liability.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Nomination forms (Form F equivalent); Proof of payment to nominee/Authority

legal_text: Subject to the other provisions of this Code, all amounts payable to an employee under this Code shall, if such amounts could not or cannot be paid on account of his death before payment or on account of his whereabouts not being known, (a) be paid to the person nominated by him... or (b) where no such nomination has been made... be deposited with the such authority, as may be prescribed.

question_text: Does the total amount of deductions made from an employee's wages in any wage period remain within the limit of 50% of such wages?
applicability_criteria: All employees undergoing deductions
simplified_guidance:
1. Calculate gross wages for the period.
2. Sum up all authorized deductions (fines, absence, damages, loans, etc.).
3. Ensure the total deduction does not exceed 50% of the gross wage.
4. If deductions exceed 50%, recover the excess in the manner prescribed by rules.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Wage Register; Pay Slips showing deduction breakdown

legal_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in this Code and subject to the provisions of any other law for the time being in force, the total amount of deductions which may be made under sub-section (2) in any wage period from the wages of an employee shall not exceed fifty per cent. of such wages.

question_text: Are all deductions made from wages strictly limited to those authorized under the Code (e.g., fines, absence, damages, amenities, loans)?
applicability_criteria: All establishments
simplified_guidance:
1. Review the list of deductions applied to employee wages.
2. Cross-reference with the authorized list in Section 18(2) (fines, absence, damage, housing, amenities, loans, tax, PF, etc.).
3. Ensure no unauthorized deductions (e.g., 'charity' without consent, arbitrary penalties) are made.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Wage Slip components; Deduction authorization forms

legal_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, there shall be no deductions from the wages of the employee, except those as are authorised under this Code.

question_text: Are fines imposed only for acts and omissions that have been approved by the appropriate Government and specified by notice?
applicability_criteria: Establishments imposing fines on employees
simplified_guidance:
1. Obtain approval from the appropriate Government/Authority for the list of acts/omissions warranting fines.
2. Display this list clearly on the premises.
3. Ensure fines are only imposed for these specific acts.
4. Do not fine for vague reasons not on the list.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Approved list of acts/omissions; Photo of notice board display

legal_text: No fine shall be imposed on any employee save in respect of those acts and omissions on his part as the employer, with the previous approval of the appropriate Government or of such authority as may be prescribed, may have specified by notice... A notice specifying such acts and omissions shall be exhibited in such manner as may be prescribed, on the premises in which the employment is carried on.

question_text: Is the total amount of fine imposed in any one wage period limited to 3% of the wages payable?
applicability_criteria: Employees subject to disciplinary fines
simplified_guidance:
1. Calculate the total wages payable for the wage period.
2. Ensure the fine amount does not exceed 3% of this total.
3. Adjust any excess fine to fall within this limit.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Register of Fines; Wage Slips

legal_text: The total amount of fine which may be imposed in any one wage-period on any employee shall not exceed an amount equal to three per cent. of the wages payable to him in respect of that wage-period.

question_text: Is the employee given an opportunity to show cause against the fine before it is imposed?
applicability_criteria: Cases where fines are proposed
simplified_guidance:
1. Issue a show-cause notice to the employee detailing the act/omission.
2. Allow the employee to explain or defend their action.
3. Record the proceedings.
4. Impose the fine only after considering the explanation.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Copy of Show Cause Notice; Employee's reply; Minutes of hearing

legal_text: No fine shall be imposed on any employee until such employee has been given an opportunity of showing cause against the fine or otherwise than in accordance with such procedure as may be prescribed for the imposition of fines.

question_text: Are deductions for absence from duty strictly proportional to the period of absence?
applicability_criteria: Employees absent from work
simplified_guidance:
1. Calculate the period of absence versus the total required work period.
2. Ensure the deduction amount matches this proportion exactly.
3. Note: If 10+ employees absent themselves in concert without due notice, deduction can include up to 8 days' wages.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Attendance Register; Wage Calculation Sheet

legal_text: The amount of such deduction shall in no case bear to the wages payable to the employed person in respect of the wage-period for which the deduction is made in a larger proportion than the period for which he was absent bears to the total period within such wage-period during which by the terms of his employment he was required to work.

question_text: Are deductions for damage or loss limited to the amount of loss caused by the employee's negligence or default, and imposed only after a show-cause opportunity?
applicability_criteria: Cases involving damage to employer property or loss of money
simplified_guidance:
1. Establish that damage/loss was directly due to employee negligence.
2. Assess the actual value of the loss (deduction cannot exceed this).
3. Give the employee an opportunity to explain.
4. Record the deduction in the register.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Damage Assessment Report; Show Cause Notice; Register of Deductions for Damage/Loss

legal_text: A deduction under clause (c) or clause (n) of sub-section (2) of section 18 for damage or loss shall not exceed the amount of the damage or loss caused to the employer by negligence or default of the employee. A deduction shall not be made under sub-section (1) until the employee has been given an opportunity of showing cause against the deduction...

question_text: Are deductions for amenities or services made only when authorized and accepted by the employee?
applicability_criteria: Employees availing housing or other services provided by employer
simplified_guidance:
1. Verify if the employee accepted the amenity/service as a term of employment.
2. Ensure the deduction does not exceed the value of the amenity supplied.
3. Check for general or special orders from the appropriate Government authorizing such services.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Employment Contract with acceptance clause; Written consent forms

legal_text: A deduction under clause (d) or clause (e) of sub-section (2) of section 18 shall not be made from the wages of an employee, unless the house-accommodation amenity or service has been accepted by him as a term of employment or otherwise and such deduction shall not exceed an amount equivalent to the value of the house-accommodation amenity or service supplied.

question_text: Are recoveries of advances made in accordance with prescribed conditions, and are travel expense advances excluded from recovery?
applicability_criteria: Employees receiving salary advances
simplified_guidance:
1. For pre-employment advances: Recover from the first wage payment (except travel expenses).
2. For post-employment advances: Follow prescribed conditions for recovery installments.
3. Ensure travel advances are not deducted from wages.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Advance Register; Wage Slips

legal_text: recovery of advance of money given to an employee before the employment began shall be made from the first payment of wages to him in respect of a complete wage-period but no recovery shall be made of such advances given for travelling expenses;

question_text: Are registers maintained to record all fines and deductions for damage or loss?
applicability_criteria: All establishments imposing fines or deductions
simplified_guidance:
1. Maintain a 'Register of Fines'.
2. Maintain a 'Register of Deductions for Damage or Loss'.
3. Record every instance, amount, and date of realization.
4. Ensure fine realizations are applied to beneficial purposes approved by the authority.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Physical or Digital Registers (Form I/II equivalent)

legal_text: All fines and all realisations thereof shall be recorded in a register to be kept in such manner and form as may be prescribed... All such deductions and all realisations thereof shall be recorded in a register to be kept in such form as may be prescribed.

question_text: Is an annual minimum bonus paid to every eligible employee who has worked for at least 30 days in the accounting year?
applicability_criteria: Employees earning wages below the notified threshold who worked 30+ days
simplified_guidance:
1. Verify the employee worked at least 30 days in the year.
2. Ensure the bonus paid is at least 8.33% of wages earned or â‚¹100, whichever is higher.
3. Confirm this is paid regardless of whether the employer has an allocable surplus.
4. Check that no eligible employee is omitted.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bonus Register (Form C); Payment proof

legal_text: There shall be paid to every employee, drawing wages not exceeding such amount per mensem, as determined by notification, by the appropriate Government, by his employer, who has put in at least thirty days work in an accounting year, an annual minimum bonus calculated at the rate of eight and one-third per cent. of the wages earned by the employee or one hundred rupees, whichever is higher whether or not the employer has any allocable surplus during the previous accounting year.

question_text: When allocable surplus exceeds the minimum bonus amount, is the bonus paid in proportion to wages, subject to a maximum of 20%?
applicability_criteria: Establishments with allocable surplus exceeding minimum bonus liability
simplified_guidance:
1. Calculate allocable surplus for the accounting year.
2. If surplus exists, increase bonus percentage above 8.33%.
3. Ensure the total bonus does not exceed 20% of the employee's wages.
4. Verify computations against the available surplus figures.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Audited Balance Sheet; Allocable Surplus Calculation (Form A/B)

legal_text: Where in respect of any accounting year... the allocable surplus exceeds the amount of minimum bonus payable to the employees under that sub-section, the employer shall, in lieu of such minimum bonus, be bound to pay to every employee in respect of that accounting year, bonus which shall be an amount in proportion to the wages earned by the employee during the accounting year, subject to a maximum of twenty per cent. of such wages.

question_text: Is the minimum bonus proportionately reduced only when an employee has not worked for all working days in the accounting year?
applicability_criteria: Employees with partial attendance during the year
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify employees who did not work all scheduled working days.
2. Apply proportionate reduction to the minimum bonus (if higher than 8.33% of actual earnings).
3. Ensure the reduction formula is mathematically consistent with days worked.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Attendance Register; Bonus calculation worksheet showing reduction logic

legal_text: Where an employee has not worked for all the working days in an accounting year, the minimum bonus under sub-section (1) of section 26, if such bonus is higher than eight and one third per cent. of the salary or wage of the days such employee has worked in that accounting year, shall be proportionately reduced.

question_text: Are days of layoff, paid leave, temporary disablement, and maternity leave included as 'days worked' for bonus eligibility computation?
applicability_criteria: Calculation of working days for bonus purposes
simplified_guidance:
1. When counting days worked, include: Layoff days, Paid leave days, Temporary disablement (accident) days, and Maternity leave.
2. Do not treat these as 'absent' for the purpose of disqualifying eligibility (30 days threshold) or reducing bonus proportionately.
3. Update attendance records to reflect these as 'deemed worked'.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Leave records cross-referenced with Bonus Register

legal_text: For the purposes of section 27, an employee shall be deemed to have worked in an establishment in any accounting year also on the days on which, (a) he has been laid off... (b) he has been on leave with salary or wages; (c) he has been absent due to temporary disablement... and (d) the employee has been on maternity leave with salary or wages.

question_text: Are employees disqualified from bonus only in cases of dismissal for fraud, riotous behavior, theft, or sexual harassment?
applicability_criteria: Employees dismissed for misconduct
simplified_guidance:
1. Check the list of employees disqualified from bonus.
2. Verify they were dismissed specifically for: Fraud, Riotous/Violent behavior, Theft/Sabotage, or Sexual Harassment conviction.
3. Ensure due process (inquiry) was followed for the dismissal.
4. Do not disqualify for minor misconducts not listed in Section 29.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Dismissal Orders citing specific misconduct; Disciplinary Inquiry Reports

legal_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in this Code, an employee shall be disqualified from receiving bonus under this Code, if he is dismissed from service for (a) fraud; or (b) riotous or violent behaviour while on the premises of the establishment; or (c) theft, misappropriation or sabotage of any property of the establishment; or (d) conviction for sexual harassment.

question_text: Is the bonus paid out of the allocable surplus calculated as 60% (banking) or 67% (others) of the available surplus?
applicability_criteria: All establishments calculating bonus pool
simplified_guidance:
1. Determine 'Available Surplus' per Section 33.
2. Calculate 'Allocable Surplus' (67% of available surplus for non-banking, 60% for banking).
3. Use this amount as the primary pool for distributing bonus.
4. Document this calculation in the statutory abstract.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Computation of Allocable Surplus (Form A); Financial Statements

legal_text: The bonus shall be paid out of the allocable surplus which shall be an amount equal to sixty per cent. in case of a banking company and sixty-seven per cent. in case of other establishment, of the available surplus and the available surplus shall be the amount calculated in accordance with section 33.

question_text: Is the principle of set-on and set-off applied correctly for allocable surplus over a four-year cycle?
applicability_criteria: All establishments liable to pay bonus
simplified_guidance:
1. If surplus exceeds max bonus (20%), carry forward the excess (Set-On) to the next year (up to 4 years).
2. If surplus is insufficient for min bonus, carry forward the deficiency (Set-Off) to be adjusted against future profits.
3. Maintain a specific register/record (Form B) tracking these set-on/set-off amounts year over year.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Set-On and Set-Off Register (Form B); Annual Returns

legal_text: Where for any accounting year, the allocable surplus exceeds the amount of maximum bonus... the excess shall... be carried forward for being set on in the succeeding accounting year and so on up to and inclusive of the fourth accounting year... Where for any accounting year... the allocable surplus... falls short... such minimum amount or the deficiency... shall be carried forward for being set off in the succeeding accounting year and so on up to and inclusive of the fourth accounting year...

question_text: Is the bonus paid to employees within a period of eight months from the close of the accounting year?
applicability_criteria: All establishments liable to pay bonus
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify the close of the accounting year (e.g., March 31st).
2. Ensure the bonus is disbursed before the 8-month deadline (e.g., Nov 30th).
3. If an extension is needed, ensure specific permission is obtained from the appropriate Government (up to max 2 years).

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bank Statement showing disbursement date; Government Order for extension (if applicable)

legal_text: All amounts payable to an employee by way of bonus under this Code shall be paid by crediting it in the bank account of the employee by his employer within a period of eight months from the close of the accounting year: Provided that the appropriate Government or such authority as the appropriate Government may specify in this behalf may, upon an application made to it by the employer and for sufficient reasons, by order, extend the said period of eight months to such further period or periods as it thinks fit; so, however, that the total period so extended shall not in any case exceed two years.

question_text: Is the bonus paid exclusively by crediting it to the bank account of the employee?
applicability_criteria: All bonus payments
simplified_guidance:
1. Review the mode of bonus payment.
2. Ensure no cash payments are made for bonus.
3. Verify bank transfer records correspond to the bonus register.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bank Advice Slip; Bank Statement referencing bonus

legal_text: All amounts payable to an employee by way of bonus under this Code shall be paid by crediting it in the bank account of the employee by his employer within a period of eight months from the close of the accounting year

question_text: If customary or interim bonus was paid earlier, is only the balance amount deducted from the final bonus payable?
applicability_criteria: Establishments that paid Puja bonus, customary bonus, or interim bonus
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify any 'Puja bonus' or interim payments made during the year.
2. Calculate the total statutory bonus liability.
3. Deduct the amount already paid from the total liability.
4. Pay the remaining balance to the employee.
5. Ensure the deduction does not exceed the amount actually advanced.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bonus Register showing advance deduction; Vouchers for interim payment

legal_text: Where in any accounting year, (a) an employer has paid any puja bonus or other customary bonus to employee; or (b) an employer has paid a part of the bonus payable under this Code to an employee before the date on which such bonus becomes payable, then, the employer shall be entitled to deduct the amount of bonus so paid from the amount of bonus payable by him to the employee under this Code in respect of that accounting year and the employee shall be entitled to receive only the balance.

question_text: Are deductions from bonus for misconduct limited to the financial loss caused and restricted to the relevant accounting year?
applicability_criteria: Employees found guilty of misconduct causing financial loss
simplified_guidance:
1. Confirm the employee was found guilty of misconduct causing *financial loss*.
2. Ensure the deduction amount does not exceed the actual loss value.
3. Ensure the deduction is applied only against the bonus of the *same* accounting year (no carry forward of deduction).
4. Pay the balance bonus, if any.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Inquiry Report establishing guilt and loss value; Bonus calculation sheet

legal_text: Where in any accounting year, an employee is found guilty of misconduct causing financial loss to the employer, then, it shall be lawful for the employer to deduct the amount of loss from the amount of bonus payable by him to the employee under this Code in respect of that accounting year only and the employee shall be entitled to receive the balance, if any.

question_text: In case of a dispute regarding higher bonus rates, is the undisputed minimum (8.33%) paid within the 8-month deadline?
applicability_criteria: Establishments with pending bonus disputes
simplified_guidance:
1. If a dispute exists claiming a higher bonus rate, do not withhold the entire amount.
2. Pay the statutory minimum (8.33%) immediately within the standard 8-month timeline.
3. Settle the differential amount later based on the dispute outcome (within 1 month of settlement).

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Proof of minimum payment; Dispute documentation
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Legal counsel advice on disputed amount

legal_text: Provided that if, there is a dispute for payment at the higher rate, the employer shall pay eight and one-third per cent. of the wages earned by the employee as per the provisions of this Code within a period of eight months from the close of the accounting year.

question_text: Does the establishment maintain a register containing details of persons employed, muster roll, wages, and other prescribed details?
applicability_criteria: All establishments (except small agriculture/domestic employers)
simplified_guidance:
1. Maintain a consolidated register (e.g., Form I or prescribed format).
2. Ensure it includes: Employee details, Muster roll (attendance), Wage calculations, Overtime, and Deductions.
3. Keep records electronically or physically as permitted.
4. Ensure entries are up-to-date and preserved for the statutory period.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Wage Register; Muster Roll; Combined Register

legal_text: Every employer of an establishment to which this Code applies shall maintain a register containing the details with regard to persons employed, muster roll, wages and such other details in such manner as may be prescribed.

question_text: Is a notice displayed at a prominent place in the establishment containing the abstract of the Code, wage rates, wage period, and Inspector details?
applicability_criteria: All establishments
simplified_guidance:
1. Prepare a notice in English and the local language.
2. Include: Abstract of the Code on Wages, Category-wise wage rates, Wage period (e.g., Monthly), Payment day/time, and Name/Address of the Inspector-cum-Facilitator.
3. Display this on the main notice board near the entrance or timekeeper's office.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Photographic evidence of Notice Board; Copy of the displayed notice

legal_text: Every employer shall display a notice on the notice board at a prominent place of the establishment containing the abstract of this Code, category-wise wage rates of employees, wage period, day or date and time of payment of wages, and the name and address of the Inspector-cum-Facilitator having jurisdiction.

question_text: Are wage slips issued to all employees in the prescribed form and manner?
applicability_criteria: All establishments (except small agriculture/domestic employers)
simplified_guidance:
1. Generate wage slips for every wage period (e.g., monthly).
2. Ensure the slip contains: Gross wages, Detailed deductions, Net pay, and Overtime details.
3. Issue these to employees electronically or physically at least a day before or on the day of payment.
4. Obtain acknowledgment (digital or physical) if possible.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Sample Wage Slips; Employee acknowledgment records; Email logs of digital slips

legal_text: Every employer shall issue wage slips to the employees in such form and manner as may be prescribed.

question_text: For employers with 5 or fewer persons in agriculture or domestic service, is reasonable proof of wage payment produced upon demand?
applicability_criteria: Small establishments in agriculture or domestic service (â‰¤5 employees)
simplified_guidance:
1. While formal registers may not be mandatory, maintain a simple record of payments.
2. Ensure you can produce 'reasonable proof' (e.g., bank transfer history, signed receipts, diary entries) if an Inspector demands it.
3. Ensure proof covers the relevant period under inspection.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Simple payment diary; Signed receipts; Bank passbook entries

legal_text: The provisions of sub-sections (1) to (3) shall not apply in respect of the employer to the extent he employs not more than five persons for agriculture or domestic purpose: Provided that such employer, when demanded, shall produce before the Inspector-cum-Facilitator, the reasonable proof of the payment of wages to the persons so employed.

question_text: Does the employer maintain sufficient records to discharge the burden of proof regarding payment of dues?
applicability_criteria: All establishments facing claims
simplified_guidance:
1. Understand that the burden of proving payment lies solely on the employer.
2. Archive all payment proofs (bank logs, signed registers, vouchers).
3. Ensure records are organized to quickly refute any claims of non-payment or unauthorized deductions.
4. Missing records will be presumed as non-payment.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Archived Wage Records; Full and Final Settlement Receipts

legal_text: Where a claim has been filed on account of non-payment of remuneration or bonus or less payment of wages or bonus or on account of making deductions not authorised by this Code from the wages of an employee, the burden to prove that the said dues have been paid shall be on the employer.
